Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is about to cross the street without looking for oncoming traffic.
Expectation2: Provide guidance to clients regarding machine usage
Situation2: A new client casually requests basic operating tips during a routine check-in call.
Story:
I was standing on the curb with my stepbrother, waiting for the light to change, when my phone buzzed. It was a new client, calling right on schedule for their first check-in. I answered, trying to keep my voice steady as I watched my stepbrother fidget impatiently beside me. The client’s questions were simple—just basic operating tips for the new machine I’d installed last week—but I could hear the uncertainty in their voice, and I knew they expected clear, reassuring guidance. 

Out of the corner of my eye, I saw my stepbrother step forward, glancing at his phone instead of the traffic. My heart jumped. I was supposed to look out for him, make sure he was safe, especially after everything we’d been through together. But the client was still talking, waiting for my answer, and I could feel the pressure to be professional, to not let them down. My mind raced, torn between shouting a warning to my stepbrother and giving the client the attention they deserved. I felt the weight of both roles pressing in, each demanding something I wasn’t sure I could give at the same time.
